bibl.title: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to W.J. Denno, January 5, 1923

div1.p: Noguchi reports to Denno on the unusual yellow fever case of seaman Cose. He believes Cose did not have yellow fever and asks for clinical records on the case.

div1.head: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to W.J. Denno, January 5, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B
Mexico
C O P Y
January 5, 1923
Dear Doctor Denno:
div1.p:
Mr Cose came to see me yesterday, and we made a
Pfeiffer test of his blood. The result was negative, both with
the Leptospira icteroides (yellow fever) and the Leptospira
icterohaemorrhagiae (infectious jaundice), which seems to indicate
that the nature of the infection in this case was neither yellow
fever nor infectious jaundice. I should like to see the clinical
record of the case, if one is available. As Mr Cose was on ship-
board the first few days of illness, he may not have been observed
closely. There are many causes of jaundice. A number of cases of
jaundice of unknown origin have occurred in the last year or two,
both in the United States and on boats running between Europe and
this country. We have tried to find the cause of these jaundice
cases, but so far no spirochetos, such as are found in yellow fever
and infectious jaundice, have been found. From Africa, also, a
number of cases of malaria with marked jaundice have been reported.
These are often confused with yellow fever. Mr Cose says he has
been taking quinine since the beginning of fever. I assume, however,
since the medical director in Tampico did not mention the finding
of malarial parasites in the blood, that none were found. If you
can get a clinical record from Tampico, I should like to see it.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, (Signed) Hideyo Noguchi Doctor W J Denno, Medical Director
Standard Oil Company
26 Broadway,
New York, N Y
